subtopic: RESUMPTION OF DEBATE ON ADDRESS IN REPLY
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would first like to thank the Hon. Member for her question; I appreciate it very much. I had a chance to review the advertisement in question. I know that she has a copy of it with her at the present time. The publisher of Penthouse magazine ran an ad in the Toronto Sun yesterday in which he likened Canada to Nazi Germany. Mr. Speaker, I think that demonstrates that a person who is incapable of making a distinction between Canada and Nazi Germany is incapable of making a distinction between pornography and art.
I fully share the Hon. Member's concern about this sort of material. She raised a very reasonable question about the law as it stands today. Once material has entered Canada, the provisions of the Customs Tariff Act no longer apply. They apply only as importation is taking place at the border.
There are three statutes which regulate this sort of material. The first is the Canada Post Corporation Act which regulates the ability of people to use the mails to transfer this sort of material. The second is the Customs Tariff Act which allows my Department to regulate the flow of this material into
November 16, 1984

Canada. The third applies after entry of the material into Canada, or if it is produced in this country, and that is the Criminal Code.
At the present time 1 know that in a number of jurisdictions the police are either considering or are in the process of laying charges under the Criminal Code. In cases where material is already in Canada, the obligation is now on the police to decide whether to lay charges. The opportunity for Customs and Excise to act has passed once the material has crossed the border.
If the Hon. Member has a concern about a particular municipality where the material is still available, and if she wants to bring it to the attention of the Attorney General of the Province of Ontario, for example, or of the local police department, she certainly has the right as a citizen to do that. The police would then consider what obligations they have under the Criminal Code.
I would like to make one other point. The Hon. Member raised questions with regard to the Customs Tariff Act as it stands today. She is absolutely right. One of the concerns that I have is that there are those three separate pieces of legislation, each of which may incorporate different standards for what is permissible in Canada and what is not. They tend to be fuzzy. They call upon us to make value judgments on this sort of material. 1 am hoping that the Fraser Committee on Pornography and Prostitution which is currently in existence and which will be making its report in a matter of weeks will be able to give us guidance on ways in which we can bring one act into conformity with the provisions of another so that there will be some certainty. Secondly, I think it would be helpful for all Canadians, for importers and for the Government if we were able to get better clarity on all three statutes so that people will know where they stand in relation to the law. To the extent to which we are capable of doing that, I think it will make the system more fair for everyone.

Member for Montreal-Mercier (Mrs. Jacques) on their fine speeches in introducing this particular motion. I believe that all Members, regardless of political affiliation, would agree with me that they distinguished themselves very well both in the quality of their speeches and in the quality of the representation they have made on behalf of their ridings. I think that that is a portent of good things to come.
I want to thank the Minister of National Revenue (Mr. Beatty), who just spoke, for the frank and candid way in which he has dealt with the problems of his Department and for the way he wants to service the needs of Canadians. I want to commend him especially for the focus he has given to the needs of those with handicaps, such as the visually impaired.
A report dealing with the problems faced by those we call handicapped has been tabled in the House for several years now. It is a pleasure to see that the Minister is taking some of those concerns to heart and is implementing them in his Department.
I know the subject of jobs has been a preoccupation with every Member of the House. I know that Members of the Opposition are trying to look for an Achilles heel in the Government on this particular issue. That is fair because that is their role. It is what they ought to do in order for them to carry out their functions. However, I believe that there are other issues.
I believe the deficit is an issue and is one reason why there are not enough jobs. When I heard it announced in the economic statement that we spend $20 billion in interest payments on our national debt, it must be an issue. That $20 billion could be spent on those who are in dire need in our country or spent on the unemployed or perhaps on pension reform.
I have never been able to understand the mind-set of the socialist party in that they want to increase indebtedness in order to help those who are in dire need. It is because of that kind of philosophy that we are $20 billion in debt and taking money away from those who need it. I hope they start looking at the economic statement from that perspective.
As I have indicated, there are other issues with which we are confronted. For example, there is the issue of ensuring that we maintain and live up to our campaign promises. That is a fair issue about which the Opposition Parties can hammer us hard to make sure we live up to those promises.
In fact, I recommend that we follow the practice which is carried in the United Kingdom where each party declares what it calls a manifesto at the beginning of the election campaign. Each party specifically outlines the issues as it sees them and how it plans to fulfil its promises if and when elected to office. Once a particular party is elected it has the burden of fulfilling those promises. The opposition recognizes that the elected government has a mandate to fulfil the philosophies that it has
November 16, 1984

explicated during the campaign, but it also has an obligation to fulfil those promises.
I sense that the Opposition, particularly the New Democratic Party, criticizes the Government for not following their agenda instead of attacking it on its agenda for the country. We were not elected to fulfil an NDP agenda but to fulfil a Conservative agenda. If we do not fulfil that agenda, then they can criticize us. But do not criticize us for not fulfilling another Party's agenda.
For that reason 1 wish that we had that kind of concept being used in Canada. I might add that in the last few elections the Liberal Party has always prescribed an agenda during an election campaign and then ignored it once it was elected. This allowed the opposition to attack those governments on almost any subject. I would simply urge the Opposition that when it attacks the Government with respect to fulfilling its mandate, as it should, it should do so on the terms that the Government laid out before the people.
Another concern we face in the country is to make sure that this place functions properly once we are elected. I was pleased that this issue was addressed in the Speech from the Throne; it is time that this institution was reformed. While this concern has been expressed before, I am pleased that the Prime Minister (Mr. Mulroney) is taking this question seriously and appointing a special committee to make sure that reform takes place.
I believe there is an underlying confusion in the minds of many of us about goals and how to reach those goals. The focus in this country and particularly in the Chamber seems to be on democracy; that we should be democratic and make democracy work, and all the other cliches connected with that term. Since the focus is on democracy, one can easily assume that the goal is democracy. I want to assure Hon. Members that while we do not want to overlook the need for democracy, that ought not to be our goal. Our goal is freedom, not democracy.

1 am glad that the Hon. Member for Regina West asked what is the difference. That absolutely demonstrates the confusion in the minds of the socialist party. Democracy is the vehicle by which we ought to deliver freedom. That does not necessarily happen. I think it is a dangerous assumption that democracy is always necessarily a friend of freedom.
Let me give the most glaring example, the Weimar Republic in 1933. It was a very democratic government in Germany, a very constitutionally democratic government.

subtopic: RESUMPTION OF DEBATE ON ADDRESS IN REPLY

It was democratically elected and it functioned democratically. It democratically elected Adolf Hitler as Chancellor of Germany. It is possible to use a good democratic institution to bring about any kind of repressive government
The Address-Mr. Friesen
you want. We should never assume just because we have a democratic government that we will always have freedom.
I think I can give another example a little closer to home. I do not want to make Members think that the odious comparison of fascist Germany-

1 do not want to make Members think that I am wrenching a comparison here when I compare what happened in Germany with what has happened in Canada. I want to point out, however, that four years ago we passed an Order in Council in this country that has been widely proclaimed as the Emergency Planning Order. That Order was passed very democratically. It was passed by a democratic government but through the powers given to that democratic government that Order in Council in its potential is incredibly repressive. It is anything but democratic. There is anything but a freedom of consensus in that particular Order.
Just because we have democracy does not necessarily mean that we have freedom. We can lose our freedom through democratic institutions. I might point out it is understandable that the New Democratic Party, rather than being called the socialist party, prefers to be called the social democratic party.

speechtext: We have been called lots of things.

speechtext: 1 hear the NDP using that term all the time, and I understand that. I understand also that the New Democrats want to be elected and they want people to vote for them. For a lot of people in Canada the term "socialism" has a pejorative ring to it and "social democratic" sounds so much better. I do not fault them on that.

There is another reason for it. Social democracy, as we have seen the experience of that particular institution around the world, has a limiting effect on freedom. It does not matter where you go, democracy is institutionalized.

speechtext: Come off it! You are drawing a long, long bow there.

subtopic: RESUMPTION OF DEBATE ON ADDRESS IN REPLY
speechtext:
I do not know whether the Hon. Member for Regina West (Mr. Benjamin) can follow a long bow. I do not know whether his attention span is long enough for that but I will try to explain to him. In order to make democracy function, it has to be institutionalized. The more you institutionalize it, the more you limit our freedom.

November 16, 1984
The Address-Mr. Friesen
At the heart of freedom is the ability to choose, Mr. Speaker. 1 think even the Hon. Member for Regina West can understand that. The ability to choose lies at the heart of freedom. The more we have our choices taken away, the more we have our choices limited, the more we lose our freedom. Some of that is logical. We have local by-laws and all of those factors that make society function where all of us concede some of our freedoms in order to make society function better. The institutions of democracy thrive on passing those kinds of laws that limit our freedom.
I want to point out why the social democrats like the term so much. I recall very clearly during the campaign the leadership debate. My Leader, the Prime Minister, and the Leader of the New Democratic Party were talking at one point about the role of banks and what the banks were doing, for example, to women. The Prime Minister made the point that women have a harder time getting credit for business transactions from the banks. The Leader of the New Democratic Party agreed. The Prime Minister went on to make another point. The Leader of the New Democractic Party asked; "Will you make it a law?" That, Mr. Speaker, is at the heart of everything that the institutionalized, democratic, call it social democratic, institutions are all about, hence the question: "Will you make it a law?" The NDP mentality is: Let us legalize or prohibit everything in a catalogue of values that they have created. Everything is good according to the value structures which the New Democrats have designed. Consequently and conversely, if they have not designed it, it has to be bad.
You see, Mr. Speaker, if you make everything according to law, automatically everybody becomes a potential law-breaker. That is what is so wrong. We focus the whole citizenry on law-keeping or law-breaking and it becomes a law-oriented society. The NDP likes that. That way New Democrats can categorize everybody to the most minuscule detail according to their criteria. "Will you make it a law?" We need some laws, I do not deny that. But that takes away from the real focus we ought to have, namely, a focus on relationships and reconciliation; whereas in a law-oriented society, which they like, we focus on law-breaking and violators. We ought to be focusing on reconciliation and relationships. That whole concept, that whole mind-set, destroys the relationships we can enjoy, Mr. Speaker.
1 recognize, as my friend the NDP heckler wants to point out to me, that we ought to have laws. Of course we ought to have laws. For example, we have the whole issue of pornography which came up in the House a few moments ago. This is an area where there needs to be legal prohibition for certain kinds of activities.

subtopic: RESUMPTION OF DEBATE ON ADDRESS IN REPLY
speechtext: Social democracy.

subtopic: RESUMPTION OF DEBATE ON ADDRESS IN REPLY
speechtext:
The criteria which New Democrats want to focus on is what you can and cannot do, whereas the focus ought to be on expanding the whole system of choices that we have in our country so we can develop our characters and our personal growth. We can do that only if we choose. The trouble with pornography is that it destroys choice, particularly when it concerns child pornography. Children's curiosity is at its highest peak, their sense of discrimination is at its lowest, and their information base is at its lowest. They do not have the tools to satisfy their curiosity as to whether or not something will help or hurt them, whether they can grow through the experience, or is know what it will do to them in future years. They are incapable of making mature choices.
Of course we ought to protect those people. We ought to preserve them in such a way so that when they become mature they can make intelligent, informed choices about how they want to live. There are no walls that one can build high enough to make sure that everybody is going to remain pure and that everybody is going to live according to the criteria that we want to establish. We cannot do that.
I see that the Hon. Member for Mount Royal (Mrs. Fine-stone) is here and I am glad that she brought up the question yesterday because I think she was honing in on this very point, that we want people to make choices on a matter of maturation so they can grow in their person rather than have their person destroyed.
I say that about much of the advertising we see on television. A lot of the advertising is not only misleading, but it is seductive when you see the kind of lifestyle advertising that is going on. It tells a false story and we need to deal with it.

speechtext:
Yes, Mr. Speaker, on a question. However, first I should like to make a brief comment. From our point of view we see laws as being necessary to establish a framework within which a co-operative community can develop. I am sure the Hon. Member would recognize that there is a need for law to restrain the selfishness of certain individuals. We recognize that need. We also recognize the need for law to protect the rights of individuals and minorities. It is on that basis that we urge law, not because, as the Hon. Member falsely tried to imply we want to see people's lives regulated in every minutia. That is a complete distortion of our political philosophy. We
November 16, 1984

want to see the largest possible measure of freedom for individuals in society. That means economic freedom to share in the goodness of society.
This brings me to the question 1 should like to ask the Hon. Member. He talked about the need for restraint. Coming as he does from British Columbia, I am sure he is aware of the 1983 budget which the Hon. Hugh Curtis introduced in that province. It is interesting that some of the same people who ran Premier Bennett's re-election campaign in 1983 were also very active in the election campaign for the Tories. They seemed to give the same advice-"Don't tell the people what you will do until after you are elected", and then whammo! The Hon. Member knows the kind of budget which was delivered in July, 1983. It promised recovery through restraint. The economic forecasts were for a 6 per cent increase in real provincial product in 1984, a 15 per cent increase in capital investment in 1984 and an employment increase of 3.9 per cent in 1984. The most recent Conference Board of Canada provincial forecasts project a decline of .1 per cent in real provincial product for this year and a decline of .9 per cent in employment. Statistics Canada projects a decline of 7.6 per cent in capital investment. In fact, the seasonally-adjusted unemployment rate in British Columbia has increased from 13.9 per cent in May, 1983 to
15.1	per cent in May, 1984. Of course, the latest figure is also
15.1	per cent unemployment.
How can the Hon. Member believe that the program of restraint being advocated by the Government will in any way improve the Canadian economy in a manner which the program of restraint of the Government of British Columbia did not? The same medicine is being prescribed by both governments. Perhaps the bedside manner of the Prime Minister (Mr. Mulroney) is a little more attractive than the bedside manner of the Premier of British Columbia. However, the medicine is the same. It has not worked in British Columbia. How will it possibly work in Canada?

Restraint is not the same. Perhaps in the Hon. Member's lexicon of terms "restraint" and "deficit" are the same word. According to the dictionary definition of those words, I do not think they are the same. I did not talk about restraint. Perhaps the Hon. Member ought to listen a little more carefully before he frames his comments.
I would estimate that about two-thirds of his comments were about the Government of British Columbia. I was not elected to defend the Province of British Columbia on that particular score. However, it reminds me of a child yelling across a fence at a bully because the bully cannot get at him. If the Hon. Member is so concerned about British Columbia, what is wrong with its economy and the approach of its government to the economy, why does he not run for the British Columbia legislature and attack them there? Why does
The Address-Mr. Friesen
he go 3,000 miles away and holler his head off at the B.C. Government?

speechtext: Mr. Speaker, could I just make a short comment in response to the Hon. Member?

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
subtopic: RESUMPTION OF DEBATE ON ADDRESS IN REPLY
speechtext: A very short comment.

subtopic: RESUMPTION OF DEBATE ON ADDRESS IN REPLY
speechtext:
In reply to the Hon. Member, I should simply like to indicate that the conditions we are seeing in Canada are the same as those we saw in British Columbia. I do not like what happened in British Columbia in the last year and a half.
I do not want that to happen in Canada. I am appealing to Hon. Members opposite to look at what happened in British Columbia so that perhaps the lessons of history can sink into their minds and there will be a change in their policy before it is too late.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons

speechtext: The Hon. Member for Gander-Twil-lingate (Mr. Baker) on a question.

subtopic: RESUMPTION OF DEBATE ON ADDRESS IN REPLY
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I do not want to ask a question. I want to make a simple comment. I do not think it would do much good to ask a question. One of the faults with the public address system is that the sound of the Hon. Member's voice is increased for those watching their television sets but it does nothing for his ideas.
I have listened to him over the years. Nothing has changed the Tory philosophy of cutting back on the deficit. The Hon. Member said that it is to help people out. According to the Hon. Member, poor people are helped by cutting back on unemployment insurance, people who just barely make ends meet are helped by increasing the price of gasoline, students are helped by discontinuing student employment programs, and public servants are helped by cutting back on Public Service jobs.
He criticized the Liberals for making promises in the election campaign of 1980 and not fulfilling them. In the last election campaign never before in the history of the British parliamentary system was so much promised by so few to so many and nothing delivered. They shook your hand before the election and then they shake you after the election.

subtopic: RESUMPTION OF DEBATE ON ADDRESS IN REPLY
speechtext:
I want to begin by complimenting the Hon. Member on his originality. He has a penchant for words, especially for phrases. Perhaps I could improve upon his phrase-Never in the field of human conflict". I appreciate the caustic barbs which he threw at me. I remember five months ago when I rose repeatedly in the House to ask him a question when he was chairman of the Standing Committee on Fisheries and Oceans. I could never get him. He was always waltzing around behind the curtain and never in his place so that I could ask him the simple question: "Why does the Standing Committee on Fisheries and Oceans, after it has given itself a mandate to travel to British Columbia and meet with the fishermen out there, not do so?" As he was chairman of that committee, I wanted to ask him why it would not go. However, he would not stay in his place. At least I am sitting here and he can ask me all the questions he wants.

speechtext: The Hon. Member for Winnipeg North Centre (Mr. Keeper) on a short question or comment.

subtopic: RESUMPTION OF DEBATE ON ADDRESS IN REPLY
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, I have a short question for the Hon. Member. He indicated that we should judge his performance or the performance of his Government on the basis of the Progressive Conservative agenda. One of the items which the Prime Minister (Mr. Mulroney) put on the agenda during the election campaign was the whole question of the universality of social programs. He said to Canadians that that was a sacred trust. Now that he is in office, he questions universality as it affects pensions and family allowances. I would like to judge their performance on the basis of the criteria which they established on their own agenda. Would the Hon. Member please respond?

subtopic: RESUMPTION OF DEBATE ON ADDRESS IN REPLY
speechtext:
Why does the Hon. Member insist upon asking such simple questions? That is no problem at all. 1 have not seen any particular kind of consistency on the part of the New Democratic Party on any other issue, let alone universality. Just as a side comment, it is strange that a company like Aluminum Company of Canada, a good Canadian company, could not make it to build a plant in Manitoba but that rotten, rotten multinational from the United States, Alcoa, seems to be able to make a deal. That is great consistency in the New Democratic Party!
To go to the point of the Hon. Member's question, his Party supported the spouses' allowance. 1 do not think they ever voted against spouses' allowance. I think his Party supported the child tax credit and hailed that as a great boon to the low-income groups, as well as the GIS. 1 would ask him whether GIS is universally applied across Canada.

subtopic: RESUMPTION OF DEBATE ON ADDRESS IN REPLY
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, first of all I would like to take this oportunity to congratulate you on your appointment. 1 may say that we on this side of the House are aware of your tremendous potential, and we would even have liked to see you on the front bench opposite. Meanwhile, we are confident that you will apply your talents wisely to presiding over this House.
1 also wish to thank my constituents in the riding of Shefford, who decided to resist the landslide on election day and show that they know the difference between a concrete program and an illusion. They refused to be tempted by the quick-fix solutions offered by the Party now in power and remained true to a Party that has done a great deal for this riding and to a Member who will continue to improve his record, I hope, in the years to come.
Mr. Speaker, I had the opportunity to read and listen to the Speech from the Throne, and to the subsequent economic statement by the Minister of Finance (Mr. Wilson), and while analysing these two documents, I concentrated more particularly on the four following issues: international trade, regional economic expansion, unemployment and youth.
Today, Mr. Speaker, I intend to demonstrate that our friends opposite have unfortunately failed to remember the commitments they made during the election campaign.
If we analyse the commitments they made during the election campaign, and then what they produced in their budget speech or economic statement, we see two totally different worlds.
For instance, during the election campaign, the Leader of the Progressive Conservative Party said on March 14: We must become first class international traders. We must become reliable suppliers of quality goods and services at competitive prices. He also said we would have to step up the search for export markets.
And finally, several weeks later, what does he offer us? A cutback of $6.2 million for the Canadian Dairy Commission, of which $4 million had been set aside for exports. 1 know some of our hon. friends from Quebec on the Government side.. .1 bet this is only the first of a series of cutbacks that will affect our dairy industry. Mr. Speaker, I am confident that in the months to come, our hon. friends opposite who promised our farmers and especially our dairy producers the moon, are going to be very embarrassed if they let the Minister of Finance take care of the dairy program, especially in Quebec.
What else did they do to increase exports? They cut another $4 million, this time from the Export Development Program. The Canadian Commercial Corporation, also concerned with exports, will lose $5 million. In the fisheries industry, one of the problems is a lack of export markets, and there they have again cut $4 million.
Finally, they said they were going to increase the number of commercial attaches. That was one of those firm commitments by the Leader of the Progressive Conservative Party (Mr. Mulroney). So one of the first cutbacks he makes in the Department of External Affairs, Mr. Speaker, involves making sure that in Rio for instance, where we had four people in the commercial section, those four positions are cut.
Mr. Speaker, that is exactly the opposite of what they said throughout the election campaign and, worse still, they made a $3.1 million reduction there. And now, of course, one of the major campaign commitments of our friends on the other side, particularly those who have hog producers in their riding, was a promise to sell their meat, but how? We had Canagrex. Well, Mr. Speaker, the first thing they did was to eliminate Canagrex; they lied openly to the agricultural producers, so what are they going to tell them when they go back to their ridings? It is a fact that hog production in Quebec, for example, amounts to 150 per cent of the requirements, but the agency on which the producers were relying has been abolished by the Progressive Conservative Party. As our friends opposite
November 16, 1984

know full well, the CIDA aid program is one of our channels to export goods and services, but there again a cut of $180 million.
Mr. Speaker, here is a political party which had promised to increase export assistance, yet their first concrete step is to reduce direct and indirect export assistance by $216.6 million. That is like talking from both sides of their mouth, yet they have the nerve to keep on saying . . . The Minister for International Trade travels around the world to say that we are going to boost our exports, but what with? Speeches just are not good enough. The speeches and promises of our friends opposite will not accomplish anything, and exporters need help. International competition is fierce and the Prime Minister may smile all he wants and the Minister for International Trade may make speeches, but that is not going to sell our products on world markets. That is one of the examples I wanted to give, Mr. Speaker.
Regional economic development is another case, particularly in areas outside Montreal and Quebec City. I saw the Minister of Communications (Mr. Masse) a few moments ago and I am wondering how he can explain to the people of Frontenac that DREE funding has been reduced by $200 million. Mr. Speaker, I wonder how several members from rural areas such as those from the Eastern Townships will explain to their constituents, after having campaigned on tourism, that tourism has been cut from the Regional Industrial Expansion Program. Have they been lying to the people or has their memory failed them?
We know quite well that the cuts in the Department of Regional Industrial Expansion affect all areas outside Montreal and Quebec City. Mr. Speaker, we know how badly many of our industries need restructuring and we are aware of the fact that some restructuring reviews have led to the saving of hundreds of jobs. The Minister of Regional Industrial Expansion (Mr. Stevens) should have known that some restructuring might be advisable in his own sphere of activity but he decided immediately to do away with the restructuring side of the Regional Industrial Expansion Program.
1 have referred to projects related to the tourist industry. I am anxious to see how the Hon. Member for Brome-Missis-quoi (Mrs. Bertrand) will manage to meet her commitments with respect to the Sutton Ski Centre, the Bromont Ski Centre, the Owl's Head Ski Centre, which were counting on the tourist section of the Regional Industrial Development Program. I am anxious to see how the Hon. Member for Megantic-Compton-Stanstead (Mr. Gerin) will manage to develop the Coaticook gorges. Although he had assumed specific commitments, Mr. Speaker, the first thing his government did was to abolish the tourist development section of the program, supposedly in a mood of consultation. Who was consulted? Which tourist interests were consulted about those cuts?
I would suggest that the levels of assistance have been lowered and, Mr. Speaker, since you also live in an area outside of Montreal, you know to what extent assistance from the Department of Regional Industrial Expansion can be badly
The Address-Mr. Lapierre
needed. You have a specific case in your area, where government help is needed but now you should forget about that, Mr. Speaker, your should forget about any large amounts for companies such as Petromont. They can no longer afford to do that, and I know very well that kind of explanations the Government and the Hon. Members will have to provide to their industrial commissioners. Over the coming months and years, hopefully, the Hon. Members opposite will recall their commitments to the people. To interpret their mandate as a mandate to cut is a serious error in my view, Mr. Speaker. I reckon that over the forthcoming months and years it will be our duty, as members of the Opposition, to hold them to their commitments. And I hope that during the upcoming debates I will have the opportunity to elaborate on cuts that have been decided against the unemployed. I hope they will realize their error soon enough.
